titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Shepard Forman papers FA1451

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-12 16:29:58 -0400.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: New York University. Center on International Cooperation

physdesc.extent: 9 boxes (3 legal document containers, 6 letter document containers)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Shepard Forman held multiple positions in the Ford Foundation related to international issues and founded the Center on International Cooperation at New York University. Forman received his Ph.D. in Anthropology from Columbia in 1966 with previous training in history, Brazilian studies, and Spanish language and literature. He completed post-doctoral work in development economics at the Institute for Development Studies at Sussex, England and field research in Northeast Brazil and Timor-Leste.

Between 1966 and 1969, he held professorships in anthropology at Indiana University, the University of Chicago, and the University of Michigan. In 1977, Forman took a leave of absence from the University of Michigan to work as a program officer for the Ford Foundation in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. In this position, he was involved in community economic and rural development while also coordinating a grantmaking program in economics and the social sciences to universities and research institutes.

In 1981, Forman became Program Officer-in-Charge of the Human Rights and Governance Program and served in that position until 1986. In 1987, the title of Program Officer-in-Charge was changed to Director. Forman served in that title until 1990. He was involved in public policy initiatives and assisted civil rights and international human rights organizations. Forman became Director of International Affairs programs at the Ford Foundation in 1991. As Director, he created a grantmaking program of research, policy analysis and public education on post-Cold War international relations. He held primary responsibility for Foundation programs in Russia and Eastern Europe and supervised 20 program and support staff in the fields of peacekeeping and disarmament, international law, international economics and development, and U.S. foreign policy. Forman left the Foundation in 1996 to found and direct the Center on International Cooperation (CIC) at New York University. The CIC's primary mission is to strengthen cooperative approaches among national governments, international organizations, and the wider policy community to advance peace, justice, and inclusion. Forman retired from the CIC in 2008. Forman served as president of the Life After Ford Foundation (LAFF) Society from 2008 until 2019.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Standard processing by Katie Martin, March 2019

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use". If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the users responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to the RAC in 2016 by Shepard Forman and was ingested in 2017 by the RAC as Accession 2017:010.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series:
4. Notepads - International Travel and Trip Notes, 1982-1986

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains photographs, correspondence, monthly calendars, and notebooks filled with trip reports and travel notes related to Shepard Forman's career at the Ford Foundation and transition to Director of the Center on International Cooperation at New York University.

relatedmaterial.p: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs, Office of the Program Director, Office Files of Shepard Forman (FA625)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence relates to Forman's tenure as Director of the International Affairs Program, transition to NYU, and the subsequent work of the Ford Foundation in international affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Calendars from Shepard Forman's tenure as Director of the Human Rights and Governance at the Ford Foundation, 1981-1991 and Director of International Affairs at the Ford Foundation, 1991-1996.

did.unittitle: Notepads - International Travel and Trip Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notebooks filled with trip reports and international travel notes from Shepard Forman's tenure as Director of the Human Rights and Governance at the Ford Foundation, 1981-1991 and Director of International Affairs at the Ford Foundation, 1991-1996. Most folders also include conference or trip agendas with names of individuals involved in meetings or presentations.
